node.title: Non-zero exit after primary job finished
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am running a customized moose on HPC with PETSC individually compiled. I sometimes receive a non-zero exit after my computing is finished. It does not seem to interrupt the computing but it does appear repeatedly. So far I have not figure out which moose object is closely related to this issue. There are input decks that would return with non-zero signal with opt executable but returned just fine with dbg executable. I am not able to reproduce this issue on local ubuntu machine or HPC with conda environment. I do not think it is due to insufficient memory because it would appear on a simple problem with single cpu and 120G memory. Sometimes I received message about corrupted double-linked list sometimes  together with non-zero exit, sometimes I did not.  gdb on this cluster is not functioning well so I cannot provide backtrace info for now.
From your experience, is this a bug need to be debugged?
The first kind of issue is exited on signal 11 (Segmentation fault):

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

mpiexec noticed that process rank 18 with PID 227203 on node solo1 exited on signal 11 (Segmentation fault).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

node.title: Reporter System Vector of Tuples
node.bodyText: I want to be able to send a vector of line segments from one multi-app to another. Is it possible to send a vector of tuples that hold the 6 coordinate values with the reporter system? I know I can send 6 reporters of each coord individually but I want to make the code cleaner and easier to read.  Let me know what would need to be done or if there was an easier way to send over a vector of line segments.

The reporter is the right data type to look at. I m not sure which one of vector of tuple or vector of vector is supported natively
@loganharbour or @zachmprince may advise you further.

Reporters just require a dataStore and dataLoad specialization for the object, plus a to_json specialization for converting to JSON.
We already have Point specialized for dataStore and dataLoad in DataIO.C. You will probably need to specialize to_json for Point in JsonIO.h. I think our library should work with the rest.
I would just give it a try and to bother me with any compiler errors on Slack. Please put up a PR for whatever you need to get this working once it's all complete.
Update... I think we'll also need to specialize a tuple

It seems like if Point already has the dataStore and dataLoad specs, I could create two more for LineSegment that use the Point store/load and a to_json for both Point and LineSegement, then I would just have a vector of LineSegments.
Yep - that should be plenty sufficient. Specialize all of the above in the location where LineSegment is declared and defined.
For the dataStore and dataLoad for LineSegment should that be in DataIO?

Nope - the convention should be that if it's not a class in MOOSE, it should be specialized there. Otherwise, it should be specialized where the object itself is declared and defined.
For example: std library things, libmesh objects, etc in DataIO. Everything else outside of DataIO

node.title: reading a vtk surface mesh file
node.bodyText:
Hi, I would like to hear your thoughts on this issue.
I have an output vtk file generated Unstructured grid that generates that outputs geometry like in the image.

So I am generating the vtk output, and I have a the code in MOOSE that basically calculates elastic energies for cylindrical shape objects where everything inside the cylinder is 1 and outside is zero.
Now here I am trying to do something different, where I have non-arbitrary objects "cylinders" and at every slice in the z-direction, it looks something like this

So now everything inside these closed surfaces is 1 and outside is zero. How can I read vtk surface mesh files files in moose, if this is something that was done before? otherwise any thoughts on this?
actually to be more precise, how do you suggest reading non-arbitrary shape objects from other software output into ones and zeros?
Can Moose read vtk format files as input?
I think MOOSE can read vtk, and if it cant there's tons of converters, such as Python's meshio to get it to a format we can read.

it seems like it does
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/mesh/FileMesh.html

Use this instead
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/FileMeshGenerator.html

actually, there is one more question, the file that is shown above is surface mesh in vtk format, I don't think moose can read surface mesh and converts to volumetric mesh.
so I am thinking of converting the vtk to stl, and surface mesh can be converted to volume mesh in msh format via gmsh.
Unless if moose can actually read surface mesh and convert to volume mesh, that would be fantastic

so read the surfaces and mesh what's in between?
MOOSE cannot do that indeed at the moment
well I would have to do surface mesh to volume mesh outside and then pass in to moose following the link above.

Okay, made progress here and this is getting interesting
I initialzed block mesh
and then I imported the mesh that I am generating from gmsh "those nanopillars" basically.

So I am just displacing them apart for visualization, but in theory the pillars should be embedded in the cube. I am using combinergenerator here by the way.
[Mesh]
[./fmg]
type = FileMeshGenerator
file = '../surface_mesh.msh'
[../]
[./gmg]
type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
dim = 3
elem_type = TET4
nx = 50
ny = 50
nz = 50
xmin = -20
xmax = 20
ymin = -20
ymax = 20
zmin = -60
zmax = 20
[../]
[./cmbn]

inputs = 'fmg gmg'
[../]
[]
So to my understanding and I looked up the source code, it seems like combinergenerator generate disjoint mesh and doesn't them combine them into one, however, this is not what I am seeing here.
I would really like to have two different pointer nodes, one existing in cube, and one existing in the nanopillars.
This is to be done for physics, because I am looping through *_current_node that is defined in AuxKernel.h
const Node * const & _current_node;
and so my question is how can I know that _current_node exists in filemeshgenerator and generatedmeshgenerator separately,
Hopefully I am making sense here, :)

CombinerGenerator makes no attempt at stitiching, and it makes no attempt at removing one volume from the other as well.
So you have two overlapping disjoint meshes right now, which I imagine is not good for your problem.
You want the nodes at the boundary of one mesh to match with the nodes at the boundaries in the other mesh right?

"You want the nodes at the boundary of one mesh to match with the nodes at the boundaries in the other mesh right?"
yes,Exactly, and then end up with two distinct meshes maybe one for pillars and for surrounding region,

why two distinct meshes? Do you want to have two different simulations?
Or do you mean two distinct subdomains?
MOOSE does not have the ability to do that.
You may try Cubit (with the python api), gmsh or Salome which should all be able to do that though it may be difficult for some

sorry mispoke, two distinct subdomains, and one simulation, but one mesh for subdomain 1, and one for subdomain 2.  It's basically like a sharp-interface problem.
Oh MOOSE can't do MOOSE can't do two subdomains?

node.title: TimeStepper System
node.bodyText:
What is the default time solving system in moose?
I see that the introduction of BDF2 only has the first time derivative format, so what method do I use for the second time derivative term?
How do I view the methods used?
Please tell me, thank you very much!

Hello
First some distinction we make is that there are both:

a TimeStepper (by default created from end_time and num_steps to be constant), which handles the size of the steps
a TimeIntegrator (by default implicit euler) which handles the time integration
All the methods may be found listed here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/syntax/Executioner/TimeStepper/index.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/syntax/Executioner/TimeIntegrator/index.html

There are dotdot() routines to get double derivatives, for example in the Coupleable interface
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classCoupleable.html#abf460b3c31b68245a81855f1656bfa43
Guillaume
thank you

node.title: How to stitch mesh A with mesh B after mesh A is cloned from another mesh?

node.bodyText:
Hello
Did you try the StitchMeshGenerator instead?
For your error, mesh2 is a pointer (unique ptr returned by the clone())
so it should be
mesh2->stitch_meshes(*mesh3, 2, 4, TOLERANCE, true, true, false, false);

A helpful resource for this is the doxygen btw
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/libmesh/classlibMesh_1_1Mesh.html
Guillaume

Thanks for your reply. I just gave it a try as you suggested and another error occurred.
class libMesh::MeshBase has no member named “stitch_meshes”

MeshBase is probably too high in the inheritance chain
Try with an UnstructuredMesh class instead

From your stack trace, I can tell this is happening in VariableValueTransferMaterial::computeProperties when computing one of your CONST MONOMIAL aux variables, which apparently depends on a material property you've declared in a VariableValueTransferMaterial. Do you know of any? I didn't even know that aux variables could depend on material properties...
If you want to see exactly where this happened, you should go to that VariableValueTransferMaterial::computeProperties frame and see which line you're on.

I didn't use VariableValueTransferMaterial to transfer any aux variables

Right, but apparently you're computing an aux variable that depends on a material property from this class.

can you tell me how you make sure that the problem is from VariableValueTransferMaterial::computeProperties

It's in your stack trace (frame number 3).
What you have here looks fine to me, but where are you using these material properties? In any aux variable? I think we discussed you bringing them into another material with the corresponding gradient material properties, so that you could compute the velocity gradient. Does this end up in aux variable at some point? If you don't think it does, do you have output_material_properties = true in your Exodus block? That would trigger making aux variables that correspond to the given material properties (via show_material_properties).
By the way, why do you need RHOEA? You're trying to compute the velocity gradient, right?

I use these material properties in a UO I've created called ADVariableTransferFromAdjacentChannelUO, similar with ADHeatFluxFromHeatStructureBaseUserObject. ADVariableTransferFromAdjacentChannelUO is 1D to 1D. I've also wrote the 1D to 1D mapping. In the Component, the code is:
  const UserObjectName adjacent_uo_name = genName(name(), "adjacent_uo");
  {
    const std::string class_name = "ADVariableTransferFromAdjacentChannelUO";
    InputParameters params = _factory.getValidParams(class_name);
    params.set<std::vector<SubdomainName>>("block") = current_flow_channel.getSubdomainNames();
    params.set<ChannelMapping *>("_channel_mapping") = &_fch_alignment;
//    params.set<MaterialPropertyName>("adjacent_a") = "_adjacent_a_coupled";
    params.set<MaterialPropertyName>("adjacent_rhoa") = "_adjacent_rhoa_coupled";
    params.set<MaterialPropertyName>("adjacent_rhoua") = "_adjacent_rhoua_coupled";
    params.set<MaterialPropertyName>("adjacent_rhoea") = "_adjacent_rhoea_coupled";
    params.set<MaterialPropertyName>("adjacent_gradrhoa") = "_adjacent_grad_rhoa_coupled";
    params.set<MaterialPropertyName>("adjacent_gradrhoua") = "_adjacent_grad_rhoua_coupled";
    params.set<ExecFlagEnum>("execute_on") = execute_on;
    _sim.addUserObject(class_name, adjacent_uo_name, params);
  }


By the way, why do you need RHOEA? You're trying to compute the velocity gradient, right?

This is because I need to calculate the pressure using RHOA RHOUA and RHOEA. The energy e is using to calculate the pressure(by p_from_v_e()). So I need RHOEA/RHOA to calculate e.

If you don't think it does, do you have output_material_properties = true in your Exodus block?

This is my input file. I think the output_material_properties is set to the dafault value(FALSE).
T_in = 300.         # K
m_dot_in = 1e-4     # kg/s
press = 1e5         # Pa

[GlobalParams]
  initial_p = ${press}
  initial_vel = 0
  initial_T = ${T_in}

  rdg_slope_reconstruction = full
  closures = simple_closures
  fp = he
[]

[FluidProperties]
  [./he]
    type = IdealGasFluidProperties
    molar_mass = 4e-3
    gamma = 1.67
    k = 0.2556
    mu = 3.22639e-5
  [../]
[]

[Closures]
  [simple_closures]
    type = Closures1PhaseSimple
  []
[]

[Components]
  [./inlet]
    type = InletMassFlowRateTemperature1Phase
    input = 'core_chan:in'
    m_dot = ${m_dot_in}
    T = ${T_in}
  [../]
  [core_chan]
    type = FlowChannel1Phase
    position = '0 0 0'
    orientation = '0 0 1'
    length = 1
    n_elems = 10
    A = 7.2548e-3
    D_h = 7.0636e-2
    f = 1.6
  [../]
  [outlet]
    type = Outlet1Phase
    input = 'core_chan:out'
    p = ${press}
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  start_time = 0
  end_time = 2
  dt = 0.1

  line_search = basic
  solve_type = NEWTON

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-5
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
  nl_max_its = 5
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

Your UO creation block doesn't raise any red flags to me. Your input file surprises me - I was expecting to see TWO flow channels and then another component to perform the coupling. Where are you putting the code that creates your UO, for example?

I don't see anything wrong with your strategy. And I agree, I don't see any aux variables that you've added.
I think you'll need to do some debugging/troubleshooting to determine why this is happening. For instance, reduce your code (comment out) to the bare minimum that you get the error. Ultimately, we need to find out why the material is in this list (frame 4) of materials that get computed for elemental aux variables, but that may be difficult.

I've got no good ideas about how to find out the error.

I wish I had the time to directly determine your error for you. The best I can do at this point is to guide you in the troubleshooting strategy and have you do it yourself. What you're doing is somewhat advanced in that we have not done this before. That being said, I still see no problem with what you're doing - it should be possible. Also, note that there is a subchannel code written with MOOSE, but I think it is not using THM channels, so if you're interested in something already written, then I can point you in that direction. If not, what you're doing is probably the right approach.
For troubleshooting strategy, comment out content in TwoChannelsModel in stages and see at which stage the error disappears:

Comment out new solution variable and associated kernels
Comment out UO
Comment out GapMaterial
Comment out gradient transfer materials
Comment out value transfer materials


are the 2 channels' variables fully coupled?

Yes, all in one nonlinear system, with one channel coupled to the other. If you were instead to use Multi-Apps/transfers, then it would no longer be fully coupled.

@joshuahansel Yes, of course. I've read about the paper which introduces the subchannel code written with MOOSE and I'm very interested in that. I'd really appreciate it if you could point me something about it.

Yes, all in one nonlinear system, with one channel coupled to the other. If you were instead to use Multi-Apps/transfers, then it would no longer be fully coupled.

I thought about using Multi-Apps before(before THM being open-source). I'm not familiar with Multi-Apps and I know it's not fully coupled. So I gave up that thought.

For troubleshooting strategy, comment out content in TwoChannelsModel in stages and see at which stage the error disappears:

Comment out new solution variable and associated kernels
Comment out UO
Comment out GapMaterial
Comment out gradient transfer materials
Comment out value transfer materials


Thanks for your advice and I will keep going using this stragedy and try to find out the error.
Thanks again for your help.
Ethan

Is there a way to obtain an MPI environment without the use of the Intel compiler/wrapper? I ask, because we have had little success using the Intel Compiler suite in the past (part of the reason why we don't support Intel compilers).

If there is a way, and you can load those modules, this will help speed up the re-building process of libMesh:
# after you loaded up a non-intel MPI environment:
export MOOSE_JOBS=4
export METHODS=opt
...then run the scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh|libmesh.sh scripts. The above will instruct libMesh to only build the optimized method (and not the opt, dbg, devel and oprof methods). Without setting a METHODS=, you build all four methods. This means building libMesh 4 times, which can be slow!

Thanks for replying!
But for me, a beginner in computer and computation, I can't fully understand your answer.
But I am trying to compile them again but still I have a question.
Could you please recommend some non-intel MPI compilers that work?
And also for your information, my problem appeared 2 days ago.
Before that, I used the Moose well for some phase-field simulations.
I wonder why the problem appeared for my posted input.
I've been confused because I expected that it is the problem of the input file or application that I built since there was no problem before that.

According to the libmesh_diagnostic.log you are on a machine/cluster which has an environment manager. You have the following environment loaded:
MODULES:
Currently Loaded Modulefiles:
  1) intel2021   2) cuda/11.2

I am suggesting that you load up a different environment which does not contain "Intel". You probably have several environments available to you. You can list them all with:
module avail
Look for modules (a string of words) which suggest something like:
openmpi-gcc-9.4.0
mvapich-gcc
mpich-gcc
# we also support LLVM/Clang compiler:
mpich-clang
mpich-llvm
openmpi-clang
When/if you find a module like this, purge your current environment and load the new one:
module purge
module load <a module you found based on the above>
...and then attempt to rebuild PETSc, libMesh, and MOOSE.
If there are no such modules available, there exists two options left to you:

Conda Packages

Normally I would not suggest using our Conda packages for an HPC environment. But this would be the easiest path forward if you are not comfortable building your own compiler stack.



or

Build your own compiler stack

I can walk you through it if you choose to accept this challenge :)

node.title: Porous Flow permeability equivalent of GenericFunctionRankTwoTensor
node.bodyText:
Hi,
Is there an easy way to use GenericFunctionRankTwoTensor to define the permeability tensor in the Porous Flow module? I've tried modifying PorousFlowPermeabilityConst to accept the name of a GenericFunctionRankTwoTensor (the functions are constant in time), but it hasn't been as straightforward as I hoped. I've also looked at the other PorousFlowPermeability... options and none of them seem to do this.
Thanks.

I had a quick look and this should be doable.
Are you planning on using an input material property or an several functions, one for each component?

Thanks - I will be using a function for each component. I have already plugged them in to a GenericFunctionRankTwoTensor though, so would be happy to just supply that as an input material property if easier.

Sounds good.
I think you could make a PorousFlowPermeabilityFromMatProp object
Please let me know where you have issues making it and I can advise you

another option would be to name your already existing material property with the expected name for the permeability.
have you tried this?

Sounds good.
I think you could make a PorousFlowPermeabilityFromMatProp object
Please let me know where you have issues making it and I can advise you

I think this would be the best idea!

Thanks for the input - after another attempt I did manage to create a "PorousFlowPermeabilityFromMatProp" object as suggested, and it's working as I'd hoped! I've attached the source and header files here (in txt format) in case they're useful to anyone in future.
PorousFlowPermeabilityFromMatPropC.txt
PorousFlowPermeabilityFromMatProph.txt
@cpgr are you interested in the contribution of these to the module?
If @ln53 is happy to contribute this I'm sure others might find it useful
Will look into it 👍

node.title: How to define a reflective BC？
node.bodyText:
Hollow, I`m a new MOOSE user.  How to define a reflective BC in the 1/4 core. Are the reflective BC described in the [Problem] or in [BC]?
Thanks!

Hello
It should be in the BC block
Which physics are you modeling? Often reflective is the same as the default no BC
Guiillaume

Thanks your answer. I want to build a 1/4 core model, the neutron flux BC in top and left are zero, and in right and bottom are mirror symmetry BC. So do I need to specify this symmetry problem in the [problem] block of the input file or specify symmetric boundary conditions in the [BC]? And how to realize the definition of mirror symmetry BC. I can't find help in the relevant instructions on the official website.
Thanks again.

For a classic diffusion problem, there's no need to specify a BC to get a reflective BC. The default is a 0 gradient (eg 0 current), which is the reflective BC.
Are you not getting a 0 gradient at the boundary with no BC?
